item.title: Summer Institute
item.dc:creator: webdev
item.content:encoded:
After consultation with the faculty, the Primary Source Cooperative has decided to forgo the 2021 summer institute. The institute is best suited for an in-person format, which we believe is not feasible this year due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. We intend on returning in summer 2022 when it’s safer for all participants to convene in Boston. Details will be posted to this page when available.

Making Past Voices Public

The Boston-Area Institute for Publishing Archival Manuscript Text Online 

The Massachusetts Historical Society (MHS) in partnership with Northeastern University Library (NUL) is proud to host Making Past Voices Public, a collegial institute from 27 to 31 July 2020 designed to assist participants with preparing the content of manuscript sources for digital public presentation. If you have/are working with archival manuscripts—letters, journals, etc.—and are seeking information about best practices for reaching high standards of accuracy, consistency, and documentation for your transcriptions and contextual information, this opportunity is for you! If you want to use TEI markup (XML) as the basis of your electronic text, this opportunity is for you! This institute is administered by the Primary Source Cooperative at the MHS and part of the Association for Documentary Editing’s education initiative, the Institute for the Editing of Historical Documents (IEHD). 

Deadline extended: 27 April 2020

Session locations: MHS, 1154 Boylston Street, Boston, and Snell Library, NUL, Boston

Details

Applications are welcome from faculty and students from a wide range of fields, as well as archivists, library professionals, public historians, and independent scholars. Small project teams are also encouraged to apply. Instructors will work with participants to determine the best process and practices to move from historical text to an authoritative online collection/edition. We will discuss how to establish well-documented policies for transcription and annotation, including how those policies translate to encoding guidelines for a TEI-based workflow. Similarly, we will explore options for moving from word-processed documents to XML and from XML files to online delivery. We will also consider reliable practices for document control and task management.

The institute will begin with a common track focused on principles of editing, and then will split into two tracks, one emphasizing project management (editorial policies, workflow options) and the other focused on XML infrastructure (encoding, schema design, transformation tools). The institute will be limited to 15 participants to ensure ample time for discussion and questions. Individual and peer-to-peer consultation to address specific issues will also be available, with an option for additional consultation time at the end of the week.

All participants are expected to have a text or a group of related texts that they have already begun to work with and hope to make public, either on their own or through an affiliated organization.

Faculty

Syd Bauman, XML Programmer-Analyst, Digital Scholarship Group (DSG), NUL

Sarah Connell, Assistant Director, Women Writers Project, DSG

Julia Flanders, Head of the DSG and Professor of the Practice of English

Nancy Heywood, Senior Archivist for Digital Initiatives, MHS

Ondine Le Blanc, Editor of Publications, MHS

Sara Martin, Editor in Chief, Adams Papers, MHS

Institute instructors are experienced with archival collections management, historical research, transcription, TEI encoding, and digital publication, and thus can offer assistance on all aspects of the digital editing process.

Fees

$250 standard fee
$150 reduced fee for students, early career professionals, and unaffiliated scholars
$50 additional fee for optional half days
The fee does not cover travel, accommodations, or food, other than the opening reception and a coffee break.
Opportunities to mitigate costs that may be associated with attending the institute include

  • housing made available on the Northeastern University campus
    and
  • travel grants (five) of $1000 each, sponsored by the IEHD.
    Interested participants will need to submit a letter specifying the anticipated costs for their travel and the absence of other sources for funding.

Questions? Contact publications [at] masshist [dot] org

item.title: Summer Institute: Preliminary Curriculum
item.dc:creator: webdev
item.content:encoded:
Day 1: Project introductions and edition goals. Participants analyze their preferred representations of primary source materials, discuss their current content management systems, think about their audiences, and settle on a publication method. 

Day 2: Policy development and implementation. Participants demonstrate document control systems, emphasizing metadata, progress tracking, and selection; they work to draft or refine transcription and annotation policies, and address any special hurdles. Discussions always relate back to edition goals. Faculty preview how tools will impact production systems and delivery of transcriptions and annotations. 

Day 3: Workflow and production systems. Participants will split into two tracks: workflow and human resources (matching tasks to skills and interests, projecting task time and tracking progress, and staff training) or technology of content generation and publication (working in Word, Word to XML, directly in XML, or in other tools optimized for XML or HTML). 

Day 4 (half day): Sustaining the edition. Participants discuss preserving published content, fundraising, budgeting for necessary tasks, and outreach. 

Days 4.5-5.5 (two half days): Participants may choose to remain for extra time consulting with individual faculty members about issues specific to their content and publishing plans.

During the program, students will have an introduction to the archival collection and document control systems at the MHS and will work in computer-optimized classrooms at Northeastern University. Participants will discuss each topic as a group and work together in small groups for concrete review and refinement of the materials they prepared before the meeting. There will be an emphasis on content analysis, especially to categorize primary types of content for which working processes can be standardized and to flag challenges and stumbling blocks that will require special treatment. Anticipated goals for the week will include creating robust and settled policies for tracking task assignment and completion, transcription, and annotation. All participants will be asked to work on transcriptions using one of the available XML-ready tools (such as CWRC-Writer or the Word Enhancement Template). The XML files produced with these tools will also be used by the participants working in the XML development track, who will be expected to have valid XML files for two (typical) project documents by the end of the Institute. A customized TEI validation schema will be available. For XML work, students will be encouraged to use oXygen, which is available for free on a 30-day trial. Each project (which may be represented by more than one participant) should complete the Institute with a usable draft for the project’s encoding guidelines and a well-defined workflow to take documents from entry in its control system to XML that is both valid and consistent with the project’s transcription, annotation, and encoding policies.

item.title: The Lab Space at DSG
item.dc:creator: mmullin
item.content:encoded:
The Digital Scholarship Group is developing a digital Lab space to showcase experiments with data analysis and visualization. The Primary Source Cooperative editions are providing early pilot projects for the Lab, where the edition data will be remixed and reshaped to reveal new patterns and interconnections. 

Scholarly editors working with the Primary Source Cooperative are creating digital editions using the TEI Guidelines: creating data which captures the structure of each individual document together with detailed metadata and information about the contents of the document, including people and topics discussed. That data is transferred via a data pipeline of the Lab’s design to bring it into the domain of the Digital Scholarship Group technical infrastructure. The raw files are stored in Amazon Web Services, and the data is indexed in an XML database to provide support for querying and for extracting specific features of the data for further analysis. From either of those endpoints, the data of the TEI is available for creative development by DSG’s analysts.

Using a combination of well-known tools, both open-source and proprietary, for natural language processing, network analysis, and visualization in Python and JavaScript, the Lab is exploring ways to begin exploration around researchers' questions -- and help them develop their own.

Below are some screenshots of prototype visualizations produced using Jupyter notebooks and the D3 visualization framework, based on data from the John Quincy Adams Digital Diaries project. 

Co-occurrence of Subject Headings

Editors at the Massachusetts Historical Society assign subject headings to each entry in John Quincy Adams's diary. The headings describe the general content of JQA's daily journal-keeping. When aggregated, these subject headings can reveal an overview of JQA's focus: the subjects he most frequently thought about when we recorded his thoughts at the end of the day.

Co-occurence of Names

The editors at MHS have also encoded references to names in order to make them available for machine analysis, and to disambiguate names. Mousing over each name highlights the name co-occurrences, as well as statistics about the network connections.

Subject Headings Across Time: Recreation

John Quincy Adams apparently wasn’t all work and no play. This chart shows the use of “Recreation” as a subject heading across time. The empty circles represent the total number of subject headings during that time period. The green circles represent usage of “Recreation”. This shows that not only does the subject appear across the range of diaries edited, but also that it is frequently among the most used subjects for each particular time period, especially early on.

item.title: About the NHPRC-Mellon Foundation Digital Editions Publishing Cooperatives Grants
item.dc:creator: oleblanc
item.content:encoded:
In 2017 the Mellon Foundation and the National Historical Publications and Records Commission, or NHPRC, launched an initiative designed to address an emerging challenge in the world of documentary editions: the expectation that an edition’s content would be available on the web. Set up in two funding stages—planning (2018) and implementation (beginning 2020)—the NHPRC-Mellon sought applications to address “the urgent need of scholars and documentary editors for reliable, sustainable, authoritative, and field-driven outlets for publication and discovery of digital editions.”

The structure of the Primary Source Cooperative reflects the stipulations of the grant initiative’s guidelines that each cooperative be made up of an edition cluster and a host institution: the four editions on the home page and the Massachusetts Historical Society. To this the PSC has also added the Digital Scholarship Group at Northeastern University as a digital derivatives partner.

The full call for the implementation grant can be found here. In order to pursue what we understood to be the most pressing goal of the Digital Edition Publishing Cooperatives initiative, the organizing team at the MHS envisioned a cooperative that would be of direct service to editors who lacked the on-team expertise and/or the institutional resources to meet the perceived digital edition mandate. We also believed that the goal should be a digitization plan that makes use of the editorial richness provided by text encoding, making an XML-based workflow desirable.
